conclusion: To determine the time at which the two cars collide, we need to analyze the velocity-time graphs of Car A and Car B.
The graphs show the velocities of the cars as a function of time.
For Car A, the initial velocity is 25 m/s and it decelerates to 0 m/s over 30 s. The equation of the line is v_A = 25 - (5/6)t.
For Car B, the initial velocity is 15 m/s and it decelerates to 0 m/s over 30 s. The equation of the line is v_B = 15 - (1/2)t.
Set the equations of the lines equal to each other to find the time t when the velocities are the same: 25 - (5/6)t = 15 - (1/2)t.
Solve for t: 25 - 15 = (1/2)t - (5/6)t implies t = -30. This result is not possible since time cannot be negative.
The distance traveled by Car A is given by the area under the v_t curve: d_A = 25t - (5/12)t^2.
The distance traveled by Car B is given by the area under the v_t curve: d_B = 15t - (1/4)t^2.
The relative distance between the cars is d_relative = d_A - d_B = 10t - (1/6)t^2.
Set the relative distance to zero: 10t - (1/6)t^2 = 0 implies t = 0 or t = 60.
The result t = 60 is not possible since it is greater than the time when the cars would have avoided colliding.
